properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: Falls Creek, Bogong, Mitta Mitta, Mount Beauty, Nelse
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Bogong, Falls Creek, Mitta Mitta, Mount Beauty, Nelse. 

  • This Community Information replaces the Community Information issued at 11:06am on Saturday 8th February.
  • Due to recent thunderstorm activity, there are currently four bushfires burning around the Falls Creek, Bogong and Alpine National Park areas.
These fires are located: 
  • 1.5km northwest of Falls Creek.
  • 5km north of Falls Creek.
  • 9km northeast of Falls Creek.
  • 19km southeast of Mount Beauty.
  • Firefighters continue to respond to these fires.
  • You will see firefighting vehicles and equipment on Bogong High Plains Road.
  • Aircraft may be operating in the area.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 06:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

COMMUNITY INFORMATION - BUSHFIRE - Stay Informed
Incident Location: Alpine National Park
Issue Date: Sunday 09 February 2025, 09:40 am
Next Update: Monday 10 February 2025, 06:00 pm

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This message is being issued for Charlton, Yeungroon, Yeungroon East.
  • There is a building fire in a hay shed on Seven Mile Road.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby roads and communities. 
  • You may see or smell smoke. 
  • Emergency services may remain in the area monitoring this fire.
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Country Fire Authority.

Unless the situation changes, this will be the last message issued for this fire.   

Health information: 
  • If you need medical advice for exposure to smoke, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 606 024. 
  • Anyone experiencing wheezing, chest tightness and difficulty breathing should call Triple Zero (000).     
Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au 
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226 
  • VicEmergency app 
  • Facebook or Twitter 
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV. 
Accessibility: 
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency. 
  • To access this information in other languages, call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Cape Horn, Apollo Bay, Cape Otway, Glenaire
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Apollo Bay, Cape Horn, Cape Otway, Glenaire.
  • The bushfire at Hordern Vale - Binns Road is under control.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice message issued Thursday 07 February 2025 at 10:48 AM.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Binns Road is currently closed.
  • Monitor traffic management signs as the road closure situation may change.
  • Firefighters are continuing to patrol this fire.
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 11:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: North East and parts of East Gippsland and Northern Country Forecast Districts
properties.webBody:
The Bureau of Meteorology has issued a Severe Thunderstorm Warning for Wodonga, Wangaratta, Corryong, Bright, Falls Creek and Mt Hotham.
  • Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce damaging winds, large hailstones and heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding in the warning area over the next several hours.
  • This Advice replaces the two Advice messages issued at 9:41 PM and 9:48 PM, Sunday 9 February. 
Be aware of potential hazards caused by the severe thunderstorm, including floodwater, trees down, fallen power lines and debris.
What you should do: 
  • Large hail is expected. Stay inside and away from windows.   
  • Be prepared for flash flooding.  
  • Park your car undercover and away from trees. 
  • Stay inside if conditions outside appear dangerous.  
  • Contact family members and neighbours to ensure they are aware of the situation, if safe to do so.
If you are driving:
  • Drive slowly, obey all road signs and never drive through floodwater.  
  • If driving conditions are dangerous, safely pull over away from trees, drains, low lying areas and floodwater. 
  • Be aware of road hazards such as mud, debris and damaged roads or bridges. 
  • For road closure information, check the VicTraffic website, contact your local council or call VicRoads (13 11 70).
Stay informed by listening to emergency broadcasters and monitoring warnings.

Call Triple Zero (000) in a life threatening emergency. 
For severe weather related emergency assistance from the SES, phone 132 500.
Impacts in your area:

The potential impacts of thunderstorms in your area include:
  • Flash flooding 
  • Fallen power lines
  • Fallen trees and branches 
  • Overflowing drains and gutters 
  • Broken windows 
  • Damage to vehicles 
  • Dangerous road conditions
This message was issued by State Emergency Service.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 01:40 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed:
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicstorms)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact the National Relay Service and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Community Information
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for Allans Flat, Kiewa, Staghorn Flat. 
  • There is a bushfire at Mount Murramurrangbong, 2km Southwest of Kiewa, that is not yet under control.
  • The fire ignited due to earlier lightning in the area.
  • Aircraft have been deployed to the fire and have since returned.
  • Firefighters will continue to monitor the fire and access the area when conditions are suitable. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for areas around Snowy Bluff, Mt Darling including Wonnangatta Valley. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued 5:42pm Saturday 8 February.
  • There is a 33ha bushfire at Mt Darling - Snowy Bluff that is not yet under control.
  • Firefighters are working to bring this fire under control and build containment lines. 
  • McMillians walking track between Moroka Junction Track and Moroka River Track is closed.
  • Rain has fallen in the fire area decreasing fire activity.
  • Heavy machinery is constructing fallback containment lines. Be aware of machines operating on Howitt Road, Moroka Road, Zeka Spur Track, Moroka Junction Track, Doolans Plain Track and Moroka River Track. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 12/02/2025 11:50 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas surrounding Little Desert National Park
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas surrounding Little Desert National Park
  • This Advice replaces the 3 Advice messages issued at 12.43 pm, 8 February.
  • The bushfire in the Little Desert National Park is now contained. 
  • Some areas of active fire may remain within containment lines
  • Fire crews will remain in the area treating hazardous trees, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines .
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes.
Impacts in your area: 
  • Major roads in the area are now open.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
  • The Little Desert National Park is closed to visitors.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit.
Smoke
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/02/2025 03:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: areas surrounding the Grampians National Park affected by the Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) fires
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for areas surrounding the Grampians National Park affected by the Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) fires .
  • This advice message replaces the Advice messages issued at 4.06 pm and 4.07 pm February 7 and 10.27 am February 8.  
  • The bushfire in the Grampians National Park - Wallaby Rocks (Victoria Range) is now contained. 
  • Some areas of active fire may remain within containment lines. 
  • Fire crews will remain in the area treating hazardous trees, monitor hot spots and consolidate containment lines. 
  • Smoke will be visible in the area. 
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • The Henty Highway is now open with reduced speed limits. 
  • Obey all speed restrictions and road closure signs.
  • Police will be patrolling the area.
  • Check the VicTraffic website (www.traffic.transport.vic.gov.au) or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians (Gariwerd) National Park
  • The Grampians Tourist road from Dunkeld to Halls gap is open. 
  • Halls Gap township is open. 
  • While most of the Grampians National Park is closed, some popular areas and visitor sites are open to the public such as the Wonderland Loop Walk which includes The Pinnacle, Venus Baths and Grand Canyon. Chataqua Peak, Clematis Falls, Bullaces Glen and Boronia Peak are also open. 
  • Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks are closed.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit.
Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000).
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 11/02/2025 04:30 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Alhambra, Jericho, Matlock, Roberts, St Clair, The Springs, Woods Point, The Triangle, A1 Mine Settlement, Gaffneys Creek
properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Alhambra, Gaffneys Creek, Jericho, Matlock, Roberts, St Clair, The Springs, Woods Point, The Triangle, A1 Mine Settlement.
  • There is a bushfire at Clarke Spur Abbot Link Track that is not yet under control.
  • This Advice replaces the Advice Message issued at 5.46pm yesterday.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Review your fire survival plan. 
  • If you do not have a plan, decide what you will do if the situation changes. 
  • Keep the roads clear so emergency services can respond. 
  • Campers at Comet Flat campground are to evacuate. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Bulldozers/aircraft are operating in the area. 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
  • The following roads are closed: Johnsons Hill Track and surrounding roads. 
  • Smoke may be visible from nearby communities and roads. 
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Vic.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 09:20 am or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: Clarke Spur Abbot Link Track
Issue Date: Sunday 09 February 2025, 09:11 am
Next Update: Monday 10 February 2025, 09:20 am

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36616/moreinfo

This Advice message is being issued for Alhambra, Gaffneys Creek, Jericho, Matlock, Roberts, St Clair, The Springs, Woods Point, The Triangle, A1 Mine Settlement.
- There is a bushfire at Clarke Spur Abbot Link Track that is not yet under control.
- This Advice replaces the Advice Message issued at 5.46pm yesterday.


There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.

properties.webBody:
This Advice message is being issued for Yarra Ranges National Park and Surrounds
  • There is a bushfire at Yarra Ranges National Park, north of Old Woods Point Road, that is not yet under control.
  • The Upper Yarra Recreational Reserve Campground has been closed.
There is currently no threat to communities, but you should continue to stay informed and monitor conditions.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
Impacts in your area: 
  • Firefighters are responding to this fire.
This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 10/02/2025 12:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#VicFires)
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:

  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service on 1800 555 677 and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

properties.name: Advice
properties.location: Yarra Ranges National Park, north of Old Woods Point Road

properties.name: Community Information
properties.location: areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire
properties.webBody:
This Community Information message is being issued for areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. 
  • The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill, known as the Yarram Gap Road fire, is under control. 
  • This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 12.47pm 7 February.
  • Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
  • Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
  • There is another fire in the western part of the Grampians known as the Wallaby Rocks Fire where fire crews continue to strengthen containment lines. Smoke may be visible from nearby communities. 
There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.
What you should do: 
  • Monitor weather conditions and warnings. 
  • Drive with caution. Obey road closure signs.  
  • Visitors are reminded to be cautious of ongoing risks and changes to the environment which may include fallen or damaged trees, smoke and injured wildlife.
  • If you see impacted wildlife - call 1300 356 682. 

Impacts in the Area:
  • Drivers may encounter fire crews and heavy machinery on roads and tracks. Please take care and drive safely. 
  • Many roads within the fire affected area remain closed. Check the VicTaffic website or call 13 11 70 for road closures.
Grampians National Park (Gariwerd)
  • The Grampians Tourist road from Dunkeld to Halls gap is open. 
  • Halls Gap township is open. 
  • While most of the Grampians National Park is closed, some popular areas and visitor sites are open to the public such as the Wonderland Loop Walk which includes The Pinnacle, Venus Baths and Grand Canyon. Chataqua Peak, Clematis Falls, Bullaces Glen and Boronia Peak are also open. 
  • Mt Abrupt, Mt Sturgeon and Piccaninny walking tracks are closed.
  • Check the Parks Victoria website for current information about where you can visit. 

Smoke:
  • Your nose is an excellent smoke detector. If you can smell smoke, take the necessary precautions to protect your health. You can self-assess the air quality near you using https://www.epa.vic.gov.au/for-community/environmental-information/air-quality/smoke/smoke-your-health.
  • Take action to reduce your exposure to smoke and protect your health: Everyone should minimise the time spent in smoky conditions whenever practical to do so.
  • People over 65 years, children 14 years and younger, pregnant women and those with existing heart or lung conditions, should reduce prolonged or heavy physical activity. Where possible (and not under direct threat from fires), also limit the time spent outdoors and when indoors, close windows and doors. If there is a break in smoky conditions, open the windows and air out your home.
  • Anyone with a heart or lung condition should take their medication as prescribed. People with asthma should follow their personal asthma action plan, continue to take preventer medication as prescribed and keep reliever medication on hand.
  • If you or anyone in your care is worried about symptoms, seek medical advice or call Nurse on Call on 1300 60 60 24.
  • Anyone experiencing difficulty breathing or tightness in the chest should seek urgent medical assistance and call Triple Zero (000). 


This message was issued by Forest Fire Management Victoria.

The next update is expected by 13/02/2025 01:00 pm or as the situation changes.

Use multiple sources to stay informed: 
  • www.emergency.vic.gov.au
  • VicEmergency Hotline - freecall 1800 226 226
  • VicEmergency app
  • Facebook or Twitter (#vicfires).
  • Tune in to ABC Local Radio, commercial and designated community radio stations, or Sky News TV.
Accessibility:
The following services can help you, or someone you know, access information during an emergency.
  • To access this information in other languages call the Translating and Interpreting Service on 131 450 (freecall) and ask them to call VicEmergency Hotline.  
  • If you are deaf, hard of hearing, or have a speech/communication impairment contact National Relay Service for assistance and ask them to call the VicEmergency Hotline.

Incident Location: Grampians National Park - Yarram Gap Road
Issue Date: Friday 07 February 2025, 07:33 pm
Next Update: Thursday 13 February 2025, 01:00 pm

More details at http://emergency.vic.gov.au/respond/#!/warning/36574/moreinfo

This Community Information message is being issued for areas east of the Grampians National Park affected by the Yarram Gap Road fire. 
- The status of the bushfire on the eastern side of the Grampians National Park between Bellfield and Bornes Hill, known as the Yarram Gap Road fire, is under control. 
- This Community Information replaces the Advice message issued at 12.47pm 7 February.
- Firefighters and heavy machinery continue to treat hazardous trees, clear tracks and rehabilitate control lines.
- Small areas of smoke within the containment area may be visible.
- There is another fire in the western part of the Grampians known as the Wallaby Rocks Fire where fire crews continue to strengthen containment lines. Smoke may be visible from nearby communities. 


There is no immediate threat to the community and no action is required.

properties.sourceTitle: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.name: Severe Thunderstorm Warning for HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.webHeadline:
Severe thunderstorms are likely to produce heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding in the warning area over the next several hours. Locations which may be affected include Wodonga, Corryong and Bright.


Severe thunderstorms are no longer occurring in the Northern Country district and the warning for this district is CANCELLED.


- 34mm of rainfall was recorded at Mt Elizabeth in East Gippsland in the 1 hour to 8:30am.
- 28mm of rainfall was recorded at Chandlers Creek in East Gippsland in the 30 minutes to 1:00pm.
- 31mm of rainfall was recorded at Weeragua (Cann River) in 3o minutes to 1:12pm.
- 28.6mm of rainfall was recorded at Mount Nowa Nowa in 30 minutes to 1:41pm.
- 27mm of rainfall was recorded at Orbost in 30 minutes to 3:13pm.

properties.sourceTitle: Severe Weather Warning for HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.name: Severe Weather Warning for HEAVY RAINFALL
properties.webHeadline:
Periods of HEAVY RAINFALL which may lead to FLASH FLOODING are possible over parts of Gippsland from Monday morning, becoming less likely through the overnight period into Tuesday. Scattered six-hourly rainfall totals between 30 and 70 mm are possible, with isolated totals of 120 mm possible.
